titleStmt.title: A relation of divers remarkable proceedings betwixt the Kings Majesty and his loyall subjects, exprest in these particulars following. 1. His Majesties speech to the gentry of the county of Yorke. attending his Majesty at his court at York, the 12. of May. 2. The answer and resolution of the gentry, and commonality of the county of Yorke, to His Majesties speech. 3. A letter of thankes from the Lords in Parliament assembled, to the county of Yorke. 4. A declaration of both houses of Parliament, as it was ordered to be printed the 12. of May. Iohn Browne, Cler. Parl. 5. Stafford-shire petition presented to the Honourable House of Commons by the knights esquires, gentlemen, ministers, free-holders, and other inhabitants of the county of Stafford.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A RELATION OF Divers Remarkable proceedings betwixt the Kings Maje≈øty and his loyall Subjects, expre≈øt in the≈øe particulars following.

list.item: 1. His Maje≈øties Speech to the Gentry of the County of Yorke, attending his Maje≈øty at his Court at York the 12. of May.
2. The An≈øwer and Re≈øolution of the Gentry, and Commonalty of the County of Yorke, to his Maje≈øties Speech.
3. A Letter of thankes from the Lords in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, to the County of Yorke.
4. A Declaration of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, as it was ordered to be printed the 12. of May. Iohn Browns, Cler. Parl.
5. Stafford-≈øhire Petition, pre≈øented to the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons by the Knights E≈øquires, Gentlemen, Mini≈øters, Free-holders, and other Inhabitants of the County of Stafford.

div.p: London, Printed for F. Ceules, and T. Bates. 1642.

div.head: HIS MAIESTIES Speech to the Gentrie of the County of York, attendng his Maje≈øtie at the City of York, on Thur≈øday the 12. of May. 1642.
div.p: I Have cau≈øe of adding not altering, what I meant to ≈øay, when I gave out the ≈øummons for this daies apperance I little thought of the≈øe Me≈ø≈øengers, or of ≈øuch a Me≈ø≈øage as they brought, the which, becau≈øe it confirmes me in what I intend to ≈øpeak, and that I de≈øire you ≈øhould be truely informed of all pa≈ø≈øages between me and the Parliament, you ≈øhall heare read. Fir≈øt, my An≈øwer to the Declaration of both Hou≈øes concerning Hull the an≈øwer of the Parliament to my two Me≈ø≈øages concerning Hull, together with my Reply to the ≈øame, and my Me≈ø≈øage to both Hou≈øes declaring the rea≈øons why I refu≈øed to pa≈ø≈øe the Bill concerning the Militia.
All which being read, His Maie≈øty proceeded.

I Will make no Paraphra≈øes upon what ye have heard, it more benefitting a Lawyer then a King, onely this ob≈øervation, ≈øince Trea≈øon in countenanced ≈øo neere me, it is time to looke to my ≈øafety: I avow it was
part of my wonder, that men (whom I thought heretofore di≈øcreet, any moderate) ≈øhould have undertaken this imployment, and that ≈øince the-came (I having delivered them the An≈øwer: you have heard, and comdmanded them to returne per≈øonally with it to the Parliament) ≈øhould have flatly di≈øobeyed mee upon pretence of the Parliaments command. My end in telling you this, is to warne you of them, for ≈øince the≈øe men have brought me ≈øuch a Me≈ø≈øage, and di≈øobeyed ≈øo lawfull a Command, I will not ≈øay what their intent of ≈øtaying here is, onely I bid you take heed, not knowing what doctrine of di≈øobedience they may preach to you, under colour of obeying the Parliament. Hitherto I have found and kept you quiet, the enjoying of which was a chiefe cau≈øe of my comming hither (Tumults and di≈øorders having made me leave the South) and not to make this a ≈øeate of Warre, as malice would (but I hope in vain) make you beleeve; Now if di≈øturbances do come, I know whom I have rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect.

To be ≈øhort, you ≈øee that my Magazine is going to be taken from me (being my owne proper goods) directly again≈øt my will; The Militia (again≈øt Law and my con≈øent) is going to be put in Execution: And la≈øtly, Sir Iohn Hothams Trea≈øon is countenanced; All this con≈øidered none can blame me to apprehend dangers. Therefore I have thought fit (upon the≈øe reall Grounds) to tell you, That I am re≈øolved to have a Guard (the Parliament having had one all this while upon imaginary Jealou≈øies,) onely to ≈øecure my per≈øon. In which I de≈øire your concurrence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and that I may be able to protect you, the Lawes, and the true Prote≈øtant profe≈ø≈øion from any Affront or Injury that may be oftered, which I meane to maintaine my ≈øelfe without charge to the Country, intending no longer to keepe them on foote, then I ≈øhall be ≈øecured of my ju≈øt Apprehen≈øions by having ≈øatisfaction in the particular before mentioned.

div.head: An An≈øwer to His Maje≈øties Speech, by the Gentry of the County of Yorke, attending his Maje≈øty at the Court of York on Thur≈øday the 12. of May, 1642.

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe Your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.

div.p: YOur Propo≈øitions delivered to Vs ye≈øterday from your Maje≈øty are of ≈øo high concernement to the Weale and peace of the whole Kingdome, and doe ≈øo nearely touch upon the affection and fidelity of all your Subjects in Generall, and wee being but a part of one County only, doe not conceive it ≈øafe for Vs to advi≈øe therein, but rather humbly to be≈øeech. Your Maje≈øty to impart the ground of Your Maje≈øties feares and jealou≈øies. to Your high Court of Parliament, (of who≈øe mo≈øt loyall care and affection to your Maje≈øties Honour and ≈øafety, and the pro≈øperity of Your Subjects and Dominions, we are mo≈øt confident) and what≈øoever ≈øhall be advi≈øed by your Great Coun≈øell, therein we ≈øhall mo≈øt willingly embrace, and give our concurrence and as≈øi≈øtance to it as ≈øhall become us; In who≈øe fidelity your Maje≈øtie hath often declared e≈øpeciall tru≈øt, and albeit we doe not pre≈øume to advi≈øe Your Maje≈øty to that particular, it being of tran≈øcendent con≈øequence.

Neverthele≈ø≈øe, in the behalfe of tho≈øe Members of Parliament, lately imployed to attend your Maje≈øty, from both Hou≈øes, being all Gentlemen of quality and e≈øtate in this County and tru≈øted to ≈øerve in that mo≈øt Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, we humbly crave Your Maie≈øties leave to expre≈ø≈øe our corfidence in their un≈øtained loyalty and affection to Your Maje≈øty to be ≈øuch as Your Maje≈øty may ≈øecurely admit their attendance to Your Maje≈øty to be ≈øuch as Your Maje≈øty may ≈øecarely admit their attendance to negotiate their imployments untill they be recalled by the Parliament, and for their fidelity we do all ingage our ≈øelves to Your Maje≈øty, and we are mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured that Your Royall Per≈øon ≈øhall be ≈øecured in the reall fidelity of Your Subjects of this County without any extraordinary Guard.

div.head: The Declaration of both Hou≈øes of PARLIAMENT.
div.p: THE Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament doe declare, That they are re≈øolved to maintaine tho≈øe Lords and Gentlemen, Committees of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, re≈øiding at Yorke, in tho≈øe things they have done, and ≈øhall further doe, in obedience of their commands, for the pre≈øerving the peace of the Kingdome.

The Lords and Commons doe declare, That if any per≈øon what≈øoever ≈øhall arre≈øt or impri≈øon the per≈øons of tho≈øe Lords and Gentlemen, or any of them, or any other Member of either Hou≈øe, that are, or ≈øhall be imployed in the ≈øervice of both Hou≈øes of Parliament; or ≈øhall offer violence to them, or any of them, for doing of any thing in pur≈øuunce of their commands, or the in≈øtructions of both hou≈øes, given unto them, ≈øhall be held di≈øturbers of the proceedings of Parliament, and publike enemies of the State. And that all per≈øons are bound by their Prote≈øtation, to endevour to bring them to condigne puni≈øhment.

The Lords and Commons doe declare, that tho≈øe of the City of London, and all other per≈øons that have obeyed the Ordinance for the Militia, and done any thing in execution thereof, have done it according to the Law of the Land, and in pur≈øuance of what they were commanded by both Hou≈øes Hou≈øes of Parliament, and for the defence and ≈øafety of the King and Kingdome, and ≈øhall have the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, again≈øt any that ≈øhall pre≈øume to que≈øtion them for yeelding their obedience to the ≈øaid command in this nece≈ø≈øary and important ≈øervice; and that who≈øoever ≈øhall obey the ≈øaid Ordinance for the time to come, ≈øhall receive the ≈øame approbation and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from both Hou≈øes of Parliament.

div.head: A Letter of thanks from the Lords in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled to the Countie of York.
div.p: THis Hou≈øe hath read the Petition from the County of York, the expre≈øsions wherein are ≈øo full of affections to the publike good of the kingdom and Parlament, that they receive it with much content, and ≈øatisfaction, and a≈ø≈øure you by mee, that your zeale to the Common-wealth, hath added much to the honour of your Countrey; commanding me in their names, to returne their very hearty thanks; the Hou≈øe concurres with you in opinion, that the onely remedy for this di≈øtracted Kingdome to recover its ancient ≈øtrength, happine≈ø≈øe, and lu≈øtre, is unity; which as it hath ever beene the ayme and ≈øcope of all their proceedings, ≈øo ≈øhall it ever be the chiefe≈øt of their endevours. And for this purpo≈øe they are already upon framing their humble de≈øires to his Maje≈øty, wherein they ≈øhall reque≈øt ≈øuch things as they conceive doe chiefely tend the honour of God, the greatne≈ø≈øe and pro≈øperity of his Maje≈øtie, and the publike good of this Common-wealth, the≈øe were almo≈øt perfected before the receipt of your Petition, and will very ≈øpeedily be to the King, which had beene done ere this, but that his Maje≈øty withdrawing him≈øelfe ≈øo farre from the Parliament, and tho≈øe many denyalls, they have had in tho≈øe things they have de≈øired, have nece≈ø≈øitated them to ≈øpend much of their time in Me≈ø≈øages, and diverted them from their other more nece≈ø≈øary bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, but they doubt not but in the≈øe de≈øires they will make ≈øuch cleare demon≈øtrations of their duty to the King, and love to his people, who have intru≈øted them, that they ≈øhall fully acquit them≈øelves thereof, both to him and them. Sir, this is what at this time I am commanded to write to you, onely adding, that I am, &c.

div.head: Stafford-≈øhire Petition, To the Honourable, the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Comons Hou≈øe of Parliament.
The humble Petition of the Knights, E≈øquires, Gentlemen, Mini≈øters, Free-holders, and other Inhabitants of the Countie of STAFORD.
div.p: THat in their owne names, and in the names of many thou≈øands of the Inhabitants of the Countie of Stafford, your Petitioners with hearts fuller of thankfulnes, than their tongues can be of expre≈ø≈øion, humbly acknowledge their ≈øen≈øiblene≈ø≈øe of the unparalelled travaile and indefatigable endevour of this Honourable Hou≈øe, already ≈øpent in the di≈øcharge of that tru≈øt de≈øervedly by the Commons of all the Land ve≈øted in you, whereby an ample Te≈øtimony is given, as of your faithfulne≈ø≈øe and courage, in the expo≈øure of your ≈øelves and fortunes in the≈øe de≈øperate times; So likewi≈øe of the good hand and providence of God, carrying you thorow many difficult ≈øtraights, and dangerous con≈øpiracies of the Popi≈øh and Malignant partie, who have hitherto way laid your proceedings.

All which your Petitioners take as very promi≈øing beginnings, and faire Pledges of the healing of the in≈øupportable grievances, both Eccle≈øia≈øticall and Civill, which the Church and State grone under; And doe concurrently and freely profe≈ø≈øe their Contributions
to the work under your hands, not only by their prayers, but al≈øo by the devotement of their lives, power, and e≈øtates, according to that wi≈øe and Religious Prote≈øtation ≈øet forth by you; concerning their owne lives and ≈øafeties to be ≈øhipt in one bottome with yours.

And your Petitioners further ≈øhew, That it is not the lea≈øt par ‚Ä¢ of their comfort, that you have continued the Militia of th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Countie unto ≈øo Honourable Lord, in whom we may ≈øafely confid ‚Ä¢

And your Petitioners doe humbly pray, That the unexampled mi≈øeries and almo≈øt expiring ≈øtate of our Brethren in Ireland, m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ be con≈øidered by an expedite di≈øpatch of ≈øea≈øonable ≈øuccour; An that they may from time to time during their mi≈øeries bee looke, upon by you, not only as Engli≈øh, and fellow-≈øubjects; but as Prote≈øtants and Profe≈ø≈øours of Gods truth, under which Notion they ≈øuffer the≈øe extremities; and that the In≈øurrection of the Papi≈øts there may be reckoned of, not onely as a Rebellion, but a horrid per≈øecution of Chri≈øt in his Truth and Members, that ≈øo the intere≈øt of God and his cau≈øe may quicken your ≈øympathy with, and endevours for them.

That the Papi≈øts (who are a great number in this ≈ømall Countie) may be thorowly and ≈øpeedily di≈øarmed, and ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed of; That they be not formidable to your Petitioners, by being able, either to keep us in jealou≈øies by their practices at home, or to ≈øoment that fire kindled by their partie in Ireland.

That the Church in her government, Officers and wor≈øhip, may be ordered according to the Rule of Gods holy Word, the particular accommodation of which wee humbly leave to the wi≈ødome of this Honourable Hou≈øe to determine, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of an A≈ø≈øembly of godly and learned Divines.

That the pre≈øent ≈øtate and condition of the Church may bee thought upon for Mini≈øtry maintenance, and ≈øupply of an able Preaching Mini≈øterie, Pluralities ≈øuppre≈øt, the Fountaines of Learning cleared; All in≈øufficient for the work of the Mini≈øtry, All gro≈ø≈øely ≈øcandalous and negligent in their ≈øunctions, removed, that they may no longer remaine a burthen to keep out others.
